section.title: Spi Controller Interface (SpiControllerIfc)
section.para: Interface containing a basic SPI controller block.

section.title: Spi Controller Block (SpiControllerBlk)
section.para: This block defines a basic SPI controller to connect general purpose peripheral SPI devices e.g., analog to digital converters, digital to analog converters and IO-port extenders.

listitem.para: Spend a dual ported RAM vendor IP instance to hold controller specific commands, transmit data and receive data.
Partition the RAM into two equally sized buffers, each to hold one transmit command/data frame and a corresponding receive data frame.
Allow a continuous flow of data between SW and HW by indicating the availibilty/preparation of a buffer by semaphores.
Provide commands to solve usual SPI transmit and receive tasks chained in a frame.

Give the possibilty to adapt this basic Spi controller block by means of inheritance to e.g, different buffer sizes, different packet lengths, repeating multipiers, dual or quad SPI-modes or to add interrupt capability.
Allow to process buffer data repeatedly in background by HW and exchange buffers only when SW wants to pay attenetion.
Allow to process intitally present data after reset autonomously by setting the reset values of respective control bits and preloading the buffers with respective transmit commands and data.

section.title: Command For Loop Cell (CmdForLoopCell)
section.para: When this command is executed it first checks if ForLoopCount is 0.
If it is not 0 it branches execution to the next immediately following command e.g. CmdGotoCell in the frame and decrements the value in ForLoopCount.
Otherwise it branches execution to the after next command.

section.title: Receive Data Cell (ReceiveDataCell)
section.para: Received data bytes as requested by tranceive command and data sequences, starting at CellBuffer start address given by CmdConfigCell.

entry.para: Receive data bytes, 4 bytes, byte at lowest address sent first, bit 0 sent first.
When this bit is set to Activated, the controller HW starts running and waits for the bit SwBuffer to be set to Prepared by SW.

When it is set, the controller HW expects a by SW prepared buffer and starts processing it. The buffer may have been prepared and the bit SwBuffer may have been set before setting the bit Activation to Activated.

When the bit Activation is set to DeActivated, the controller is actually deactivated after the current HW buffer and an eventually pending prepared SW buffer have been processed completely. This can be monitored by reading the HwBuffer state in the StatusReg.
Set the controller to be activated or check if it is activated.
Set the controller to be deactivated or check if it is deactivated.

SW writes the value Prepared to this bit when it has completely prepared the frame content of a SW owned buffer, thus committing its ownership to HW. The value isn’t stored and cannot be read back by SW. Solely the write access triggers the commit action.
Notify HW to take ownership of a prepared buffer prepared.
Writing this value has no effect.

The bits of HwBuffer show Off when the controller is completety deactivated. This is the case if it hasn’t been activated yet or if it has been deactivated. For the later case the bits HwBuffer show Busy until all pending prepared SW buffers have been processed by HW and then show Off.
The bits of HwBuffer show Idle when HW is waiting for a prepared SW buffer.
The controller has processed the last buffer after deactivation and is off now.
The controller has not yet or no more buffers prepared by SW to be processed by HW.
The controller is busy and processing a buffer prepared by SW.
Any value written has no effect.
HW sets this bit to Available, when it has completely ended processing a HW owned buffer, thus committing its ownership to SW.
The first two sequentially presented buffers to SW after a controller activation contain undefined data.
The following buffers necessarily had been processed by HW already. They contain their previous frame transmit content and the received data collected during their already completed processing by HW.
After the SW has processed the frame receive data in the buffer, it prepares the new frame transmit data e.g. modify or keep its previous frame content or write a completely new frame content.
Then SW sets SwBuffer to Prepared to hand it over to HW to be processed.
